title: ds.dynamical systems - Confusion on the assumption when discussing the kneading invariants for unimodal maps
body: A unimodal map is a continuous map $f:[0,1]\longrightarrow [0,1]$ such that there is only one turning point (critical point), denoted by $c$ , and $f(0)=f(1)=0$ . Unimodal map is related to kneading invariant and kneading map, constructed by Hofbauer and Keller. One assumption is always being made by several books in dynamics. They all assume $$f^{2}(c)<c<f(c),$$ where $f^{n}(x)$ is the $n-$ times iteration of $f$ at $x$ . They all use an one-line explanation: If this condition does not hold, then $f$ has no interesting dynamics. I have drew several pictures but I cannot see why. Even though we have $c<f^{2}(c)<f(c)$ , the dynamics is still complicated, since I cannot see a clear rule about where $f^{n}(c)$ will go for $n\geq 3$ . So what does it mean by "interesting" here? and why does this assumption make the dynamics "interesting"? Thank you! ds.dynamical-systems complex-dynamics definitions symbolic-dynamics Share Cite Improve this question Follow asked Jun 25, 2020 at 19:56 JacobsonRadical 131 4 4 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 4 1 $\begingroup$ In this case, the interval $I=[c,f(c)]$ is mapped into itself and the restriction of $f$ to $I$ is decreasing. This means that every orbit in $I$ converges either to a fixed point or a period two orbit. For points in $[0,c]$, the orbit is either monotonic (and so converges to a fixed point), or it eventually leaves $[0,c]$, whereupon it enters $I$. For points in $[f(c),1]$, the image is in $[0,f^2(c)]\subset [0,c]\cup I$, so that we have shown that every orbit approaches a fixed point or period 2 orbit. Pretty dull... $\endgroup$ Anthony Quas –  Anthony Quas 2020-06-26 02:34:25 +00:00 Commented Jun 26, 2020 at 2:34 $\begingroup$ @AnthonyQuas brilliant! Post an answer so that I can accept and vote? $\endgroup$ JacobsonRadical –  JacobsonRadical 2020-06-26 13:51:31 +00:00 Commented Jun 26, 2020 at 13:51 $\begingroup$ @AnthonyQuas could you please elaborate a little bit why every orbit in $I$ converges either to a fixed point or a period two orbit? $\endgroup$ JacobsonRadical –  JacobsonRadical 2020-06-26 14:00:17 +00:00 Commented Jun 26, 2020 at 14:00 $\begingroup$ The point is $f$ is a decreasing map from $I$ to $I$, so that $f^2$ is an increasing map from $I$ to $I$. It's pretty easy to see that if you have an increasing map, everything converges to a fixed point. Probably math.stackexchange.com would be a better place if you want to ask about that. $\endgroup$ Anthony Quas –  Anthony Quas 2020-06-26 16:05:04 +00:00 Commented Jun 26, 2020 at 16:05 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
